transcript:
Patient: It's interesting to think about where my inner critic comes from. I know a lot of it has to do with the messages I received growing up, both from my family and from society at large. As a transgender person, I've always felt like I had to work twice as hard to prove my worth and be accepted.

Therapist: That makes a lot of sense, Jamie. Growing up with those messages can really shape the way we see ourselves and the world around us. And as a transgender person, you've likely faced unique challenges and barriers that have contributed to the development of your inner critic.

At the same time, it's important to remember that those messages and experiences don't define your worth or value as a person. You are inherently worthy and valuable, regardless of what anyone else says or thinks.

As we continue to explore the roots of your inner critic, it can be helpful to practice extending compassion to that part of yourself. This might mean acknowledging the pain and fear that your inner critic is trying to protect you from, while also recognizing that you don't need to be perfect or meet anyone else's standards in order to be worthy of love and acceptance.

Patient: That's a powerful reminder. It's hard to break free from those old messages, but I know that I don't want to keep living my life according to someone else's standards.

Therapist: Exactly. And as you continue to practice self-compassion and challenge those old messages, you'll start to develop a new, more empowering narrative for yourself. One that recognizes your inherent worth and value, and allows you to live life on your own terms.

Before we wrap up for today, I want to check in on how you're feeling. What's your mood like now, and do you have any final thoughts or questions?

Patient: I'm feeling a bit lighter than when we started, actually. It's helpful to talk through these things and to be reminded that I'm not alone in this journey. I don't have any specific questions right now, but I appreciate you checking in.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that you're feeling a bit lighter, Jamie. It's a testament to the hard work you're doing in therapy and the progress you're making. Remember, every small step counts, and every moment of self-compassion is a victory.

For homework this week, I'd like you to continue practicing your cognitive restructuring and self-compassion skills, using the thought records and coping cards we've discussed. I also invite you to spend some time reflecting on the roots of your inner critic and practicing extending compassion to that part of yourself.

In our next session, we can continue to explore the themes we've discussed today, and check in on your progress with the homework. We can also start to think about what you want to focus on in our remaining sessions together, and how you can continue to support yourself after our work together comes to an end.

Patient: That sounds good. I appreciate you giving me some direction for the homework and for our upcoming sessions. It helps me feel more grounded and focused in this process.

Therapist: I'm glad that the structure and direction are helpful for you, Jamie. Remember, this is your therapy journey, and I'm here to support you in whatever way works best for you. If there's ever anything you'd like to discuss or focus on that we haven't covered, please don't hesitate to bring it up.

Thank you for your hard work and openness today, Jamie. I'm really proud of the progress you're making, and I'm excited to continue this journey with you.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed and practiced cognitive restructuring and self-compassion skills using examples from the patient's week
  - Explored the roots of the patient's inner critic and practiced extending compassion to that part of themselves
  - Discussed strategies for staying motivated to practice self-care and self-compassion on difficult days, including creating a crisis plan and breaking down practices into smaller steps
  - Checked in on the patient's current mood and provided encouragement and support

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Cognitive restructuring: Practiced identifying and reframing negative thoughts using the CBT triangle framework. Plan to continue practicing this technique daily, using thought records.
  - Self-compassion: Discussed building a self-compassion toolkit with go-to phrases for common triggering situations. Plan to continue practicing self-compassion techniques, including setting an intention each morning and using the personalized self-compassion plan.
  - Positive Data Log: Reviewed the importance of accumulating evidence for new, more balanced core beliefs. Encouraged patient to continue adding to their log as part of their homework and to practice deepening techniques to internalize new beliefs.
  - Coping cards: Discussed creating coping cards with reminders of adaptive thoughts, strategies, and new core beliefs to support the patient after therapy. Plan to create personalized affirmations and mantras to reinforce positive beliefs.
  - Crisis plan: Introduced the idea of creating a crisis plan for difficult days, including reaching out to trusted friends or family members, engaging in comforting activities, and having a pre-written text or email to send when struggling.

- Homework assigned:
  - Set aside time each day to practice cognitive restructuring using thought records
  - Continue building self-compassion toolkit with go-to phrases for common triggering situations
  - Practice setting a daily intention to look for evidence of inherent value and add to Positive Data Log
  - Engage in at least one act of self-care each day, even if it's something small like taking a short walk or enjoying a cup of tea
  - Reflect on the roots of the inner critic and practice extending compassion to that part of themselves

- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms, and important personal details:
  - Patient reported feeling a mix of emotions since the last session, with some good days where they felt more motivated and hopeful, but also days where they felt really down and struggled to get out of bed
  - Patient demonstrated increased insight into the role of self-criticism and perfectionism in their life and how it contributes to feelings of depression and inadequacy
  - Patient expressed willingness to practice new techniques and strategies for managing self-criticism and promoting self-compassion, but acknowledged that it can be challenging to break old habits
  - Patient's cultural background and personal beliefs may influence their experience of depression and approach to treatment

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Negative core belief: "I'm not valuable or worthy as a person."
  - Intermediate belief: "If I'm not perfect or successful, then I'm not valuable or worthy."
  - New, more balanced core belief: "I have inherent value as a person, regardless of my successes or failures."

- Plan for the next session:
  - Review cognitive restructuring, self-compassion, and Positive Data Log homework and discuss any challenges or insights
  - Continue working on reframing negative core beliefs and developing more balanced and compassionate beliefs
  - Explore patient's experience with practicing self-compassion and self-care, and discuss any changes in mood or overall well-being
  - Brainstorm additional self-care ideas and discuss strategies for motivation
  - Discuss any other topics or concerns that may arise
  - Introduce additional CBT techniques, such as mindfulness or problem-solving, as needed
